quickScenarioChallenge.challengeSubtitle: Don't worry if you get it wrong‚Äîthat's how you learn!
quickScenarioChallenge.scenarioStory: You're starting a new software development project. HR gives you a list of 15 available developers. You can select anyone, but you notice that while some have excellent technical skills, they have poor collaboration skills. Others are great team players but lack some technical expertise. You need a team of 8 developers.
quickScenarioChallenge.question: What should guide your team selection FIRST?

options.A: Select the 8 developers with the highest technical skills regardless of personality
options.B: Select based on project needs, considering both technical skills AND ability to work collaboratively
options.C: Let the developers self-select into teams based on their preferences
options.D: Select the 8 developers with the most experience

ahaDebrief.correctAnswer: B - Balance technical skills AND collaboration ability

insights.principle: Not Everyone is Good for Every Team
insights.explanation: Team composition matters. The best individual performers don't always make the best team. Balance skills, personalities, and collaboration ability.
insights.pmbokSupport: High-performing teams require both competence and collaboration

insights.explanation: Different projects need different team compositions. Consider project type, complexity, and stakeholder expectations when building the team.
insights.pmbokSupport: Teams should match the specific needs and expectations of stakeholders

insights.explanation: Sometimes you select the team (ideal). Sometimes the team is assigned to you (common). Either way, you must develop them into a high-performing unit.
insights.pmbokSupport: Project managers develop teams regardless of how they're formed

trapSection.explanation: Building a team isn't just about finding the best individuals‚Äîit's about creating a cohesive, collaborative unit.

trapTable.pmiValueBroken: Technical brilliance without teamwork creates conflict and dysfunction

trapTable.violation: Abdicates leadership responsibility for team composition
trapTable.pmiValueBroken: May create cliques or imbalanced teams

trapTable.violation: Experience doesn't guarantee fit for this specific project

coreFramework.frameworkIntro: Building a high-performing team requires intentional design and development:

rows.action: Define what this specific project needs. Technical skills? Domain knowledge? Agile experience? Regulatory expertise? Not all teams fit all projects.
keyQuestions: What skills does THIS project require?
What's the complexity and risk level?
rows.examKeywords: Project requirements, Skills needed, Technical competencies, Domain expertise

rows.action: Assess who's available (if selecting) or who's assigned (if team is given). Understand their skills, personalities, strengths, and collaboration abilities.
keyQuestions: Can I select the team or is it assigned?
What are each person's technical skills?
What are their working styles and preferences?
rows.examKeywords: Assess talent, Skills inventory, Team composition, Available resources

rows.action: Build diversity of thought, background, and perspective. Diverse teams innovate better and catch more blind spots. Balance experience levels.
keyQuestions: Mix of junior and senior members?
rows.examKeywords: Diversity, Inclusion, Different perspectives, Balance, Cognitive diversity

rows.action: Develop the team through Forming ‚Üí Storming ‚Üí Norming ‚Üí Performing. Facilitate team charter, ground rules, working agreements. Build cohesion.
keyQuestions: What stage is the team in (Tuckman)?
Do we have a team charter?
How can we accelerate to performing?
rows.examKeywords: Team development, Tuckman stages, Team charter, Ground rules, Cohesion

rows.action: Foster collaboration, trust, and shared accountability. Remove silos. Celebrate wins together. Make the team greater than the sum of individuals.
rows.examKeywords: Collaboration, Trust, Shared accountability, Team synergy, Collective intelligence

tuckmanStages.forming: Team members are polite, getting to know each other. Low productivity.
tuckmanStages.storming: Conflicts emerge as personalities clash. Critical to navigate well.
tuckmanStages.norming: Team establishes norms and working agreements. Productivity increases.
tuckmanStages.performing: High trust, high performance. Team is self-organizing.
tuckmanStages.adjourning: Project ends, team disbands. Celebrate and capture lessons.

pmbokConnection.quote: Not everyone is good for every team, and not every team is good for every project. Teams should be built with intention and developed continuously.

secondScenario.title: üéØ Apply the B.U.I.L.D. Framework
secondScenario.scenarioStory: You're assigned a team of 10 people for a mobile app project. You didn't select them‚ÄîHR assigned them based on availability. The team has never worked together before. Three members are experienced iOS developers, two are Android experts, three are backend developers, and two are new graduates. Personalities range from introverted to very outspoken. The project kicks off in one week.
secondScenario.question: Following B.U.I.L.D., what should you do FIRST?

options.A: Request to replace the new graduates with experienced developers
options.B: Assess the team's skills against project needs, then facilitate a team charter session to establish ground rules and build cohesion
options.C: Immediately assign work based on their technical specialties
options.D: Let the team self-organize since you didn't select them

quotes.text: Not everyone is good for every team and not every team is good for every project. Even if you select the team members, you have to develop that team.

fieldInsights.title: The Tuckman Reality
fieldInsights.insight: All teams go through Forming (polite) ‚Üí Storming (conflict) ‚Üí Norming (agreements) ‚Üí Performing (high output). You can't skip Storming‚Äîit's where trust is built through navigating conflict. Your job: help them get through Storming quickly and productively.

fieldInsights.title: Assigned vs. Selected Teams
fieldInsights.insight: In reality, you rarely get to select your entire team. More often, they're assigned based on availability. That's okay‚Äîyour job is to DEVELOP whoever you get into a high-performing team. Selection is a luxury; development is a necessity.

fieldInsights.title: Diversity Drives Innovation
fieldInsights.insight: Homogeneous teams feel comfortable but miss blind spots. Diverse teams (background, thought, experience) may have more initial friction but produce more innovative solutions and catch more risks. Facilitate inclusion, not just diversity.

story.title: Building Your Summit Team
story.narrative: You're **BUILD**ing your expedition team for K2. Follow the steps...

scenes.visual: üìã Create the BLUEPRINT of what you need
scenes.description: Not all teams fit all mountains. K2 needs technical ice climbers, high-altitude experience, crevasse rescue skills, medical expertise. That's your project needs. Don't copy Everest's team blueprint‚Äîdesign for THIS mountain.

You meet candidates: Sarah (expert ice, 8000m peaks), Marcus (strong but first 8000m), Chen (doctor, 6000m max), Eva (assigned by sponsor, didn't choose her). You understand their skills and experience. Not who you'd pick ideally, but these are your options.

You need ice expertise, medical skills, high-altitude veterans, fresh perspectives. Different specialties, different experience levels. Marcus brings enthusiasm. Sarah brings wisdom. Chen brings safety. Diversity makes the team stronger.

scenes.visual: üöÄ LAUNCH team development at base camp
scenes.description: Week 1 is Forming (polite introductions). Week 2 is Storming (Sarah and Marcus disagree on route). Week 3 is Norming (they establish climbing protocols). Week 4 is Performing (moving fast together!). You facilitate through Tuckman stages.
They work as one unit. Sarah leads ice sections. Marcus handles heavy loads. Chen monitors health. Eva documents the climb. Shared accountability. Summit reached. Greater than the sum of individuals.

story.moral: Building an expedition team isn't random‚Äîit's **B**lueprint needs, **U**nderstand climbers, **I**ntegrate diversity, **L**aunch development, **D**eliver collaboratively. That's B.U.I.L.D.

memoryPalace.selfTest: Close your eyes. Picture base camp. Can you see **B**lueprinting needs, **U**nderstanding climbers, **I**ntegrating specialties, **L**aunching through Tuckman, **D**elivering the summit? That's B.U.I.L.D.
